title: 109_hr2982
content: The Act may be cited as the "FCC Reorganization Act" and includes findings. The Congress finds that the organization of the Federal Communications Commission's bureaus based on technology type is outdated due to new technologies allowing companies to offer multiple services. The FCC's regulatory function and structure are addressed in Section 3. The FCC's regulatory function and structure are addressed in Section 3. Subsection (b) of section 5 of the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. 155(b)) is amended to reorganize the Commission's staff into bureaus and divisions based on the purposes of the regulation to be administered. The FCC reorganizes its staff into bureaus and divisions, including a Spectrum Management Bureau, Government Affairs and Consumer Education Bureau, and Economic Regulations Bureau. The FCC reorganizes its staff into bureaus and divisions, including Spectrum Management, Government Affairs, Consumer Education, Economic Regulations, Public Interest, and Broadcast Content bureaus. These bureaus have specific responsibilities related to various regulatory issues in the telecommunications industry. The FCC reorganizes its staff into bureaus with specific responsibilities related to regulatory issues in the telecommunications industry, including broadcast content, licensing, enforcement, and international matters. The Commission will periodically re-examine the organization of the bureaus every 5 years. The FCC periodically re-examines and reorganizes its bureaus every 5 years to ensure they meet the Commission's requirements. Each bureau is staffed with personnel necessary to perform its functions. The amendment made by section 3 of the Act will be effective 18 months after enactment, with the FCC authorized to begin implementation and compliance on the date of enactment.
